metadata.case_name: Management of Hindustan Steel Ltd., Ranchi v. Hindustan Steel Ltd. Employees Union, Ranchi

facts.text: Shri R. Venkatesan Naidu (Shri Naidu) recruited to work-charged establishment of Ranchi Housing Project in March 1960 on consolidated salary of Rs. 250/- p.m., post purely temporary subject to termination with or without notice.
Shri Naidu joined duty on March 15, 1960 after accepting conditions.

Shri Naidu applied for post of Overseer in response to advertisement; offer made on June 15, 1960 for appointment as Overseer upto March 31, 1961, extendable, purely temporary terminable without notice or reason.
Shri Naidu assumed charge as Overseer on June 20, 1960.
Construction and connected residuary work of Ranchi Housing Project over by end of 1966; decided to wind up project and retrench 13 workmen effective December 31, 1966 after notice and compensation.
Services of three executives and two Overseers (Shri Naidu and Shri Verghese) retained to finalise accounts and residuary work.
Management attempted to secure employment for these five in sister units like Bokaro Steel Ltd., but unsuccessful; Shri Naidu lacked basic qualifications.

Tenure extended upto June 30, 1968; departmental committee considered absorption in Central Engineering and Design Bureau, but Shri Naidu (Class IX only, no technical qualification) could not be absorbed.
Services retrenched effective afternoon of June 22, 1968; financial concurrence for Ranchi Housing Project residuary work expired same date.
Prior to Hindustan Steel Ltd., Shri Naidu served as construction foreman in Damodar Valley Corporation Ltd. 1950-1957.
Applied on February 18, 1960 to Hindustan Steel Ltd. for technical post, mentioning Senior Cambridge standard and 23 years service.
Offered Works Supervisor on March 10, 1960; later Overseer, joined May 20, 1960.
Charge-sheeted June 10, 1964 for shortage of steel rods; enquiry found guilty, dismissed January 13, 1965.
Labour Court, Ranchi under S.25 Bihar Shops and Establishments Act held dismissal unjustified/illegal, ordered reinstatement April 13, 1966; resumed duties May 7/10, 1966.
Charge-sheeted again May 12, 1966 for falsely stating passed Senior Cambridge; filed civil suit for declaration of mala fides.
Retrenchment order dated June 29, 1968 purporting under S.25F Industrial Disputes Act, alleged mala fide.
Applied April 18, 1960 for Overseer, mentioned Cambridge Senior; offered by office order 14/15 June 1960, joined by June 30, 1960.
Construction closed end 1966, 13 workmen retrenched, Naidu continued for residual work; project wound up 1968, notice Ex.7 for retrenchment June 29, 1968 as surplus, no alternative employment.
Ranchi Housing Project and Maintenance Division separate; project temporary, wound up March 31, 1968; genuine efforts to absorb Naidu failed.
Retrenchment notice Ex.7 informed compensation from cashier within two days, subject to no-demand certificates.

legal_issues.text: Whether the retrenchment of Shri Venkatesan (Shri Naidu), Ex-Overseer, is proper and justified? If not, what relief?
Whether S.25F(b) or S.25FFF(2) of Industrial Disputes Act applies to the retrenchment?
Whether retrenchment notice defective as conditional, violating S.25F(b)?
Whether principle of 'last come first go' under S.25G applies?
Whether retrenchment mala fide, unfair labour practice or victimisation?

petitioner_arguments.text: Shri Naidu's appointment purely temporary, terminable without notice; Ranchi Housing Project wound up, services retrenched bona fide after failed absorption efforts.
Case governed by S.25FFF, not S.25F(b); Ranchi Housing Project is 'undertaking' closed down; as construction project, no compensation under S.25F(b) required.
Notice Ex.7 complies with S.25F(a); defect in notice not specifically pleaded, management taken by surprise; general pleas do not cover specific statutory defect.
No unfair labour practice, victimisation or mala fides; management's discretion to decide labour strength.

respondent_arguments.text: Retrenchment mala fide due to big bosses' unhappiness after reinstatement; prior dismissal illegal, reinstated by Labour Court.
Notice defective under S.25F(b) as compensation not paid at time of retrenchment, conditional on no-demand certificates, deferred to within two days.
Last come first go principle not followed; unfair labour practice.
Not closure of entire undertaking, only Housing Project; S.25FFF inapplicable.

court_reasoning.text: Ranchi Housing Project distinct undertaking with beginning and end, closed down; separate office; Tribunal finding correct.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Undertaking' in S.25FFF means any work, enterprise, project or business undertaking, not entire industry.

court_reasoning.text: S.25FFF applies; creates fiction of retrenchment under S.25F, but cl.(b) not attracted for closure; notice complies with S.25F(a).
court_reasoning.key_observation: For construction undertakings closed on completion within 2 years, no compensation under S.25F(b); here project fits closure.

court_reasoning.text: Plea of notice defect not specifically pleaded; general pleas in written statement do not cover; management surprised.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Statutory defect plea must be specific and precise.

court_reasoning.text: Temporary appointment terms contrary to last come first go; S.25G inapplicable; no unfair practice.
No evidence of mala fides, victimisation or unfair practice.

holdings.text: Ranchi Housing Project closure falls under S.25FFF; S.25F(b) inapplicable; retrenchment notice valid under S.25F(a).
Defect in notice plea not raised specifically; cannot be considered.
Retrenchment proper, justified and legal; no reinstatement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hari Prasad Shiv Shankar Shukla v. A. D. Divekar
precedents_cited.relevance: S.25F not for bona fide closure, led to insertion of S.25FFF.

precedents_cited.case_name: Workmen of the Indian Leaf Tobacco Development Co. Ltd. v. Management
precedents_cited.relevance: Closure of part (8/21 depots) is closure under S.25FFF.

precedents_cited.case_name: Parry & Co. Ltd. v. P. C. Lal
precedents_cited.relevance: Managerial discretion in reorganisation leading to surplusage justifies retrenchment.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Conditions for retrenchment; compensation on closure of undertaking; last come first go principle.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Shops and Establishments Act, 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: Labour Court ordered reinstatement against prior dismissal.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Tribunal's award set aside; held retrenchment of Shri Naidu proper and justified under S.25FFF as closure of Ranchi Housing Project undertaking; notice valid; no violation of S.25F(b) as inapplicable.

key_quotes.text: The word undertaking as used in S.25FFF seems to us to have been used in its ordinary sense connoting thereby any work, enterprise, project or business undertaking.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of 'undertaking' for closure provisions.

key_quotes.text: The plea of the statutory defect in the notice should, in our opinion, have been reasonably specific and precise so as to enable the appellant to meet it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects general plea covering notice defect.

key_quotes.text: We are, therefore, constrained to allow the appeal, set aside the impugned award and hold that the retrenchment of Shri Naidu was proper and justified.
key_quotes.speaker: court
